s.text: Until recently, millions of green-card holders were content to live in the United States as resident aliens.
(Immigration and Naturalization Service estimates show that 5.8 million of the 10.
(Immigration and Naturalization Service estimates show that 5.8 million of the 10.
But of late, lawmakers have indicated a change of attitude toward legal immigrants, and this has affected the number of applications for citizenship.
According to INS estimates, 300,000 illegal immigrants come to the United States each year, and there were 5 million illegal immigrants living in the country in 1996.
But of late, lawmakers have indicated a change of attitude toward legal immigrants, and this has affected the number of applications for citizenship.

In FY 1996, 915,900 people received an immigrant visa (a "green card"--it's actually pink), which makes them eligible for permanent residence and most of the benefits of citizenship, with the important exception of the right to vote.

Candidates for citizenship must 1) be 18 or older; 2) have resided in the United States continuously for five years--or three years if married to a U.S. citizen--(short absences are OK); 3) demonstrate the ability to speak English, and a basic knowledge of American history and government (click here to see if you pass the test); and 4) be of "good moral character."
